body:
Thanks for finding and reporting this issue! (will fix)
we should definitely add back 3.7 for K80 support which is widely available in public clouds.
3.5 is probably not needed as k40 is not widely adopted as k80?

issue.title: add k80 support for CUDA11

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
-clean up cuda build flags for jetson/arm
-address https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/4935  , where k80 support was missing after we added CUDA11 support. k80 is still widely available on Azure, GCP etc. so we need to continue supporting it.

body:
I used to use a lot of K40, and probably many labs heavily invested at that
time still have K40 (at least I'm still seeing it around).
And also GeForce 770-780Ti, "dirt cheap" in today's standard but can still
be found in dev desktop (and still not weak enough to justify an upgrade).

On Thu, Aug 27, 2020 at 8:24 PM George Wu <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Thanks for finding and reporting this issue! (will fix)
> we should definitely add back 3.7 for K80 support which is widely
> available in public clouds.

From  LTL

will discuss with team about what flags to include (and which archs we want to support in our packages). issue is we don't want to enable every flag by default. they do have some impact on the build time and binary sizes.

Seems the decision is to keep only 3.7?
AFAIK the difference between 3.5 and 3.7 is only a few registers, and 3.5 should be compatible with 3.7, but not the other way.
So if no noticeable perf difference, maybe keeping 3.5 is better than 3.7?

This is just general suggestion, not a request, as we enable all of them in our build anyway.

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.

revisiting this old thread. @xkszltl, is k80 still being used?
Nvidia has already deprecated sm37 since tensorrt 7.1 and are looking at removing support entirely. 
They wanted feedback on the timing.

For me I'm not using any K80 at this point personally, although I do still found their active use in academical environment.

Sample deployments there're still alive:
- https://www.tacc.utexas.edu/systems/chameleon
- https://rcc.uchicago.edu/support-and-services/midway2
- https://xstream.stanford.edu/specs/
- https://www.marcc.jhu.edu/hardware/
- https://wiki.gacrc.uga.edu/wiki/GPU_Hardware

And Cloud providers, including us, are still having K80 as well:
- https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/nc-series
- https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/p2/

So from deployment point of view, Kepler works way better than Fermi and gained a huge installation base at that time, it may not be decommissioned that quickly.
But once that's "gone", we can probably fast-forward to Pascal since Maxwell is just a transitional product.

Regarding whether to keep supporting K80, my suggestions would be:

- See if support with trt7 can be kept for a while, if so K80 user can simply stick to the old version.
- Check for library compatibility inside cmake, when user is trying to compile for sm35/sm37, and provide clear error msg if it doesn't work.
- Upon removal of the support, create a rock-solid version as the last version so that K80 use can still have something to fallback to.

Regarding timing:

Tesla K80 was launched in Nov 2014, < 7 years ago, and it's quite reasonable to ask for 10-year support on a professional hardware.
So IMO nvidia is not doing a great job here, for deprecating sm35/sm37 in driver that early.

Maybe you can also talk to Azure teams to see how long do they plan to keep those NC-series machines?
